Architecture

Backbone: Distributed, typed WebDatasets with atdata
The OpenAstrocytes dataset is built on atdata, an open-source package we’re developing at Forecast for distributed, interoperable usage of AI-ready datasets. atdata is built on the open WebDataset format, designed for use as a high-performance AI I/O layer.The original motivation for atdata internally was to have fast infrastructure for putting together our rich, multimodal datasets to speed up the iteration cycle for our R&D;
atdata makes it straightforward to understand structured data from remote repositories:
import numpy as np
import matplotlib.pyplot as plt
from style import HouseStyle

import atdata
from openastros.datasets.uncaging import MovieFrame

dataset_url = 'https://research.forecast.bio/datasets/astrocyte_nts-{0000..0024}.tar'

# `atdata` uses generigs to annotate sample types
dataset = atdata.Dataset[MovieFrame]( dataset_url )

# Under the hood, `atdata`take care of downloading, caching, buffering,
# unpacking samples, etc.
for batch in atdata.shuffled( batch_size = 32 ):
    labels = np.array( batch.labels )
    frames = batch.data
    # Just pull the first batch
    break

with HouseStyle() as s:
    plt.figure()
    plt.imshow( frames[0] )
    plt.show()
atdata’s typing functionality already helps for keeping datasets sane; but, where keeping track of sample types really shines is when we register mappings between types:
from atdata.schemas import LabeledImage

@atdata.projection
def project( sample: MovieFrame ) -> LabeledImage:
    return LabeledImage(
        image = sample.data,
        label = sample.label
    )
This design enables us, as we’re building AI models from a bunch of different sources, to easily aggregate across our diverse hive of WebDatasets across modalities and experiments that are able to be compatibly merged. The full atdata ecosystem is architected to go one step further, placing metadata for type schemas of scientific datasets—and the code for these lenses between them—in a public, decentralized repository on ATProto, the protocol layer underlying the Bluesky social network. This allows AI coding agents on data science tasks to automatically leverage domain knowledge of structured semantic relationships to decide what data to pull from for a given task.More on atdata soon—sign up for updates to hear first as we push more features to the public release!
